items.synopsis: All 13 hospitals in Gaza have been given Israeli evacuation orders, according to the UN. There are more than 117,000 people staying in the facilities it says. Follow live.

title.children: More than 1.4 million displaced in Gaza as all 13 hospitals given evacuation orders, UN says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The head of the UN's agency for Palestinian refugees warns "an immediate humanitarian ceasefire has become a matter of life and death for millions". The United Nations Relief and Works Agency's Philippe Lazzarini stressed "the present and future of Palestinians and Israelis depend on it". He warned during an emergency meeting of the UN's Security Council that a further breakdown of civil order, following the recent break-ins at the agency's warehouses by panicked Palestinians searching for food and other aid, will make it extremely difficult for the UNRWA to continue operating. Mr Lazzarini said most Palestinians in Gaza "feel trapped in a war they have nothing to do with" and "they feel the world is equating all of them to Hamas". Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Immediate ceasefire 'a matter of life and death'

children.content: The head of the UN's agency for Palestinian refugees warns "an immediate humanitarian ceasefire has become a matter of life and death for millions".
The United Nations Relief and Works Agency's Philippe Lazzarini stressed "the present and future of Palestinians and Israelis depend on it".

He warned during an emergency meeting of the UN's Security Council that a further breakdown of civil order, following the recent break-ins at the agency's warehouses by panicked Palestinians searching for food and other aid, will make it extremely difficult for the UNRWA to continue operating.
Mr Lazzarini said most Palestinians in Gaza "feel trapped in a war they have nothing to do with" and "they feel the world is equating all of them to Hamas".
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As of October 30 more than 1.4 million people in Gaza were "internally displaced", according to the UN's latest updates. "This figure includes nearly 672,00 people staying in 150 UNRWA facilities, 121,750 sheltering in hospitals, churches, and other public buildings, and nearly 83,000 in 72 non-UNRWA schools," the organisations latest humanitarian update says. "In addition, the Ministry of Social Development estimates that some 700,000 internally displaced persons (IDPs) are residing with host families." It adds giving assistance to around 300,000 displaced people in 100 centres is "increasingly challenging" because of the intensity of air strikes and hostility. "The average number of IDPs per shelter in UNRWA facilities has reached almost four times their intended capacity. "The Khan Younis Training Centre is currently the most crowded shelter, hosting 22,100 IDPs, more than 10 times its capacity. "Over 15 per cent of the IDPs are estimated to have disabilities, yet most shelters are not adequately equipped for their needs. "Shelters lack the required medical mattresses and beds, causing ulcers and other medical issues that cannot be treated in sterilised conditions."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gaza's shelters operating at four times capacity as 1.4 million displaced

children.content: As of October 30 more than 1.4 million people in Gaza were "internally displaced", according to the UN's latest updates.

"This figure includes nearly 672,00 people staying in 150 UNRWA facilities, 121,750 sheltering in hospitals, churches, and other public buildings, and nearly 83,000 in 72 non-UNRWA schools," the organisations latest humanitarian update says.
"In addition, the Ministry of Social Development estimates that some 700,000 internally displaced persons (IDPs) are residing with host families."
It adds giving assistance to around 300,000 displaced people in 100 centres is "increasingly challenging" because of the intensity of air strikes and hostility.
"The average number of IDPs per shelter in UNRWA facilities has reached almost four times their intended capacity.
"The Khan Younis Training Centre is currently the most crowded shelter, hosting 22,100 IDPs, more than 10 times its capacity.
"Over 15 per cent of the IDPs are estimated to have disabilities, yet most shelters are not adequately equipped for their needs.
"Shelters lack the required medical mattresses and beds, causing ulcers and other medical issues that cannot be treated in sterilised conditions."

image.altText: Smoke emerges from bushland around Tara where fires are ongoing.

title.children: Over 50 homes lost with more expected, as authorities warn Tara fire is 'erratic' and 'uncontrolled'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: QFES Chief Superintendent Warren Buckley has told the community meeting at Tara that 53 homes have been lost and that number is expected to rise.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Number of homes lost in fires expected to rise again in Tara

children.content: QFES Chief Superintendent
Warren Buckley
has told the community meeting at Tara that 53 homes have been lost and that number is expected to rise.

props.alt: A group of people sit for a community meeting in Tara.

children.content: (ABC News: Laura Cocks)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ABC's Tobias Loftus is there, and says Western Downs Mayor Paul McVeigh told the crowd of about 50 people that evacuation centres remain open. Warren Buckley from the Queensland Fire and Emergency Services said today is going to be a massive day for fire activity, with about 120 firefighters on the ground. “It’s erratic, it’s uncontrolled and not contained,” he said. Strike teams from Victoria will arrive tomorrow, but some equipment from the southern state has already arrived. Support from New Zealand will arrive later this week.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A community meeting is underway in Tara, with authorities warning the fire is 'erratic' and 'uncontrolled'

children.content: The ABC's

is there, and says Western Downs Mayor Paul McVeigh told the crowd of about 50 people that evacuation centres remain open.

children.content: (ABC News: Tobias Loftus)
Warren Buckley from the Queensland Fire and Emergency Services said today is going to be a massive day for fire activity, with about 120 firefighters on the ground.
“It’s erratic, it’s uncontrolled and not contained,” he said.

props.alt: Warren Buckley from the Queensland Fire and Emergency Services speaks into a microphone.

children.content: (ABC News: Tobias Loftus)
Strike teams from Victoria will arrive tomorrow, but some equipment from the southern state has already arrived.
Support from New Zealand will arrive later this week.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you missed it a little earlier, the Prime Minister was in Bundaberg and said the government was expecting "some 42,000 claims as a result of these fires so far". "[Emergency] Minister Murray Watt is visiting that area today to see what other support can be offered," he said. "I spoke to David Littleproud the local member yesterday and offered my support. "Victorian and New Zealand crews will soon be on the ground there to help. These are heartbreaking scenes when people lose their their houses."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Anthony Albanese says at least 42,000 recovery claims expected after Tara bushfire

children.content: If you missed it a little earlier, the Prime Minister was in Bundaberg and said the government was expecting "some 42,000 claims as a result of these fires so far".
"[Emergency] Minister Murray Watt is visiting that area today to see what other support can be offered," he said.
"I spoke to David Littleproud the local member yesterday and offered my support.
"Victorian and New Zealand crews will soon be on the ground there to help. These are heartbreaking scenes when people lose their their houses."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank has warned that there could be "a regime shift characterized by structurally higher interest rate volatility" in the years ahead. In a speech on emerging threats to financial stability on Tuesday, RBA assistant governor Brad Jones said supply shocks, a higher and more volatile bond term premium, and reduced smoothing from price-insensitive buyers were the potential contributing factors to a structurally higher interest rate volatility, despite that much of the past two decades saw long-term interest rate volatility either decline or languish at unusually subdued levels. He said a period of structurally higher interest rate volatility would present several challenges to financial system stability. "Banks of all sizes will have to manage overall duration risk more intently," Mr Jones said. "Over much of the past few decades, growth in incomes consistently exceeded the level of interest rates. This dampened credit risks for lenders. But debt servicing among borrowers with high debt levels will be more challenging – and credit risks will increase as a result – in an environment where interest rates periodically exceed the growth in incomes. "The post-GFC era of exceptionally low interest rate volatility gave rise to a new generation of investment business models and strategies. "It remains to be seen how market functioning could be affected in a regime of higher inflation and interest rate volatility, including where open-end fixed-income funds encounter liquidity stress, margining is more tightly enforced than in the past, and broker-dealers are unable or unwilling to supply liquidity."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA warns of 'a regime shift characterized by structurally higher interest rate volatility'

children.content: The Reserve Bank has warned that there could be "a regime shift characterized by structurally higher interest rate volatility" in the years ahead.
In a speech on emerging threats to financial stability on Tuesday,
RBA assistant governor Brad Jones

said supply shocks, a higher and more volatile bond term premium, and reduced smoothing from price-insensitive buyers were the potential contributing factors to a structurally higher interest rate volatility, despite that much of the past two decades saw long-term interest rate volatility either decline or languish at unusually subdued levels.
He said a period of structurally higher interest rate volatility would present several challenges to financial system stability.
"Banks of all sizes will have to manage overall duration risk more intently," Mr Jones said.

"Over much of the past few decades, growth in incomes consistently exceeded the level of interest rates. This dampened credit risks for lenders. But debt servicing among borrowers with high debt levels will be more challenging – and credit risks will increase as a result – in an environment where interest rates periodically exceed the growth in incomes.
"The post-GFC era of exceptionally low interest rate volatility gave rise to a new generation of investment business models and strategies.

"It remains to be seen how market functioning could be affected in a regime of higher inflation and interest rate volatility, including where open-end fixed-income funds encounter liquidity stress, margining is more tightly enforced than in the past, and broker-dealers are unable or unwilling to supply liquidity."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Superannuation fund AustralianSuper said on Tuesday it plans to vote against a Brookfield-led consortium's $US9.78 billion takeover offer for Origin Energy, casting doubt on the future of the bid. AustralianSuper owns a 13.68 per cent stake in Origin Energy and said the offer was "substantially below" its estimate of long-term value for Australia's biggest energy retailer. Origin shares were down 0.9 per cent in early trade on Tuesday at $9.10 each, which was above the $8.81 offer price. The deal requires 75 per cent support from the votes cast at a shareholder meeting, meaning AustralianSuper's holding could be enough to scupper the bid if not all shareholders vote. Brookfield-consortium's offer price of $8.81 per share has been deemed fair by an independent expert's report, however, it outlined a "roll forward" calculation that says Origin's shares could be worth an additional 40 Australian cents by the time a potential takeover is due to occur. The Brookfield-led consortium has given no indications publicly it is considering upping the value of its bid. "No doubt the negotiations between the bidders and key shareholders like AustralianSuper are ongoing," said Max Vickerson, analyst at stockbroker Morgans. "Given that AusSuper felt the need to go public it suggests that maybe they're not that close to a deal. It's hard to say definitively that the takeover won't happen as someone could still blink before the vote but it’s not a good sign." Origin shares have been trading above the offer price since the deal got an approval from the country's competition regulator on October 10. Origin shares closed at $9.17 on Monday, 4.1 per cent above the offer price. AustralianSuper, which engaged consultancy firm Frontier Economics to review the independent expert's report, said the firm was also of the opinion that the assumptions used to come at a business valuation were "unrealistically low". "The current offer from the Brookfield and EIG-backed consortium remains substantially below our estimate of Origin's long-term value," the firm said. Brookfield and EIG's MidOcean Energy did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AustralianSuper to vote against Brookfield's $US9.8b offer for Origin Energy

children.content: Superannuation fund AustralianSuper said on Tuesday it plans to vote against a Brookfield-led consortium's $US9.78 billion takeover offer for Origin Energy, casting doubt on the future of the bid.
AustralianSuper owns a 13.68 per cent stake in Origin Energy and said the offer was "substantially below" its estimate of long-term value for Australia's biggest energy retailer.
Origin shares were down 0.9 per cent in early trade on Tuesday at $9.10 each, which was above the $8.81 offer price.
The deal requires 75 per cent support from the votes cast at a shareholder meeting, meaning AustralianSuper's holding could be enough to scupper the bid if not all shareholders vote.

Brookfield-consortium's offer price of $8.81 per share has been deemed fair by an independent expert's report, however, it outlined a "roll forward" calculation that says Origin's shares could be worth an additional 40 Australian cents by the time a potential takeover is due to occur.
The Brookfield-led consortium has given no indications publicly it is considering upping the value of its bid.
"No doubt the negotiations between the bidders and key shareholders like AustralianSuper are ongoing," said Max Vickerson, analyst at stockbroker Morgans.

"Given that AusSuper felt the need to go public it suggests that maybe they're not that close to a deal. It's hard to say definitively that the takeover won't happen as someone could still blink before the vote but it’s not a good sign."

Origin shares have been trading above the offer price since the deal got an approval from the country's competition regulator on October 10. Origin shares closed at $9.17 on Monday, 4.1 per cent above the offer price.

AustralianSuper, which engaged consultancy firm Frontier Economics to review the independent expert's report, said the firm was also of the opinion that the assumptions used to come at a business valuation were "unrealistically low".
"The current offer from the Brookfield and EIG-backed consortium remains substantially below our estimate of Origin's long-term value," the firm said.
Brookfield and EIG's MidOcean Energy did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.
Reuters
